(KEM) ciphertext.definition: A bit string that is produced by encapsulation and used as an input to decapsulation.

(p, t)-completeness.definition: For a given set of n variables, (p, t)-completeness is the proportion of the C(n, t) combinations that have configuration coverage of at least p.

(t + k)-way combination coverage.definition: For a given test set that provides 100% t-way coverage for n variables, (t+k)-way combination coverage is the proportion of (t+k)-way combinations of n variables for which all variable-values configurations are fully covered.

[<i>T</i>]<sub>2</sub>.definition: A binary representation for the integer T (using an agreed-upon length and bit order).

{<i>X</i>}.definition: Used to indicate that data X is an optional input to the key derivation function.

<em>(n, d)</em>.definition: RSA private key in the basic format.

<em>(n, e, d, p, q, dP, dQ, qInv)</em>.definition: RSA private key in the Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT) format.

<em>(p, q, d)</em>.definition: RSA private key in the prime-factor format.

<em>(r, s)</em>.definition: Digital signature for DSA or ECDSA.

<em>[a, b]</em>.definition: The set of integers x, such that a ≤ x ≤ b.

<em>[x]m</em>.definition: The binary representation of the non-negative integer x, in m bits, where x<2m.

<em>[x]s</em>.definition: The binary representation of the non-negative integer x, in s bits, where x<2s.

<em>{a1, ...ai}</em>.definition: The internal state of the DRBG at a point in time. The types and number of the ai values depends on the specific DRBG mechanism.

<em>{x, y}</em>.definition: A set containing the integers x and y.

<em>|x|</em>.definition: The length of a bit string X in bits.

<em><strong>leftmost (V, a)</strong></em.definition: The leftmost a bits of V.

<em><strong>len (a)</strong></em>.definition: The length in bits of string a.

<em><strong>min (a, b)</strong></em>.definition: The minimum of a and b.

<em><strong>rightmost (V, a)</strong></e.definition: The rightmost a bits of V.

<em><strong>select (V, a, b)</strong></e.definition: A substring of string V consisting of bit a through bit b.

<em><strong>X • Y</strong></em>.definition: The product of two blocks, X and Y, regarded as elements of a certain binary Galois field.

<em><strong>xmodn</strong></em>.definition: The unique remainder r (where 0£ r £ n-1) when integer x is divided by n. For example, 23 mod 7 = 2.

<em>∇ψ2m(obs);∇2ψ2m(obs)</em>.definition: A measure of how well the observed values match the expected value. See Sections 2.11 and 3.11.

<em>0s</em>.definition: For a positive integer s, 0s is the string that consists of s consecutive 0 bits.

<em>0x</em>.definition: A string of x zero bits. For example, 05 = 00000.

<em>0x0X</em>.definition: 8-bit binary representation of the hexadecimal number X, for example, 0x02 = 00000010.

<em>0xab</em>.definition: Hexadecimal notation that is used to define a byte (i.e., eight bits) of information, where a and b each specify four bits of  information and have values from the range {0, 1, 2,…F}. For example, 0xc6 is used to represent 11000110, where c is 1100, and 6 is 0110.

<em>a mod b</em>.definition: The modulo operation of integers a and b. “a mod b” returns the remainder after dividing a by b.

<em>A(i)</em>.definition: The output of the ith iteration in the first pipeline of a double pipeline iteration mode.

<em>AES(k, input)</em>.definition: A single AES encryption operation as specified in [FIPS 197] with k and input being the AES encryption key and one 128-bit block of plaintext/data, respectively.

<em>Alen</em>.definition: The bit length of the associated data.

<em>Alphabet size</em>.definition: The number of distinct symbols that the noise source produces.

<em>Alphabet</em>.definition: A finite set of two or more symbols.

<em>assurance_level</em>.definition: The level of assurance (e.g., HIGH, MEDIUM, or LOW) that a claimed signatory possesses the private signature key.

<em>B</em>.definition: The bit string to be determined

<em>Bi</em>.definition: The ith block of the formatted input.

<em>Binary data (from a noise source)</e.definition: Digitized output from a noise source that consists of a single bit; that is, each sampled output value is represented as either 0 or 1.

<em>bLen</em>.definition: The length of the bit string B in bits

<em>C*n</em>.definition: The last block of the ciphertext, which may be a partial block.

<em>CIPH-1K(X)</em>.definition: The inverse cipher function of the block cipher algorithm under the key K applied to the data block X.

<em>CIPHK(X)</em>.definition: The forward cipher function of the block cipher algorithm under the key K applied to the data block X.

<em>Clen</em>.definition: The bit length of the ciphertext.

<em>Cn</em>.definition: Block of data representing the Ciphertext n

<em>Conditioning (of noise source output.definition: A method of processing the raw data to reduce bias and/or ensure that the entropy rate of the conditioned output is no less than some specified amount.

<em>Confidence interval</em>.definition: An interval estimate [low, high] of a population parameter. If the population is repeatedly sampled, and confidence intervals are computed for each sample with significance level α, approximately 100(1− α) % of the intervals are expected to contain the true population parameter.

<em>Continuous test</em>.definition: A type of health test performed within an entropy source on the output of its noise source in order to gain some level of assurance that the noise source is working correctly, prior to producing each output from the entropy source.

<em>Cumulative Distribution Function (CD.definition:
A function giving the probability that the random variable X is less than or equal to x, for every value x. That is, 
F(x) = P(X £ x).

<em>D</em>.definition: A payload of data that is assembled and transmitted by the message signatory, which includes (at least) the message and a digital signature, and may also include one or more timestamps.

<em>d</em>.definition: The normalized difference between the observed and expected number of frequency components. See Sections 2.6 and 3.6.

<em>Destruction</em>.definition: The process of overwriting, erasing, or physically destroying a key so that it cannot be recovered.

<em>Dictionary</em>.definition: A dynamic-length data structure that stores a collection of elements or values, where a unique label identifies each element. The label can be any data type.

<em>Digitization</em>.definition: The process of generating bits from the noise source.

<em>dP</em>.definition: RSA private exponent for the prime factor p in the CRT format, i.e., d mod (p - 1); an integer.

<em>dQ</em>.definition: RSA private exponent for the prime factor q in the CRT format, i.e., d mod (q - 1); an integer.

<em>E[ ]</em>.definition: The expected value of a random variable.

<em>e</em>.definition: The original input string of zero and one bits to be tested.

<em>eBits</em>.definition: The bit length of the RSA exponent e.

<em>ei</em>.definition: The ith bit in the original sequencee.

<em>enc8(i)</em>.definition: For an integer i ranging from 0 to 255, enc8(i) is the byte encoding of i, with bit 0 being the low-order bit of the byte.

<em>Entropy rate</em>.definition: The rate at which a digitized noise source (or entropy source) provides entropy; it is computed as the assessed amount of entropy provided by a bitstring output from the source, divided by the total number of bits in the bitstring (yielding the assessed bits of entropy per output bit). This will be a value between zero (no entropy) and one.

<em>Estimate</em>.definition: The estimated value of a parameter, as computed using an estimator.

<em>Estimator</em>.definition: A technique for estimating the value of a parameter.

<em>F</em>.definition: Standard Normal Cumulative Distribution Function (see Section 5.5.3).

<em>fn</em>.definition: The sum of the log2 distances between matching L-bit templates, i.e., the sum of the number of digits in the distance between L-bit templates. See Sections 2.9 and 3.9.

<em>GCD(a, b)</em>.definition: Greatest Common Divisor of two positive integers a and b. For example, GCD(12, 16) = 4.

<em>GCTRK (ICB, X)</em>.definition: The output of the GCTR function for a given block cipher with key K applied to the bit string X with an initial counter block ICB.

<em>GHASHH (X)</em>.definition: The output of the GHASH function under the hash subkey H applied to the bit string X.

<em>gir</em>.definition: DH key exchange value, also called a DH shared secret (in IKE version 2).

<em>Global performance metric</em>.definition: For a predictor, the number of accurate predictions over a long period.

<em>gxy</em>.definition: Diffie-Hellman (DH) key exchange value, also called a DH shared secret (in IKE version 1).

<em>H(M)</em>.definition: A hash value that is generated on M.

<em>H(x)</em>.definition: A cryptographic hash function with x as an input.

<em>h</em>.definition: An ECC domain parameter; the cofactor, a positive integer that is equal to the order of the elliptic curve group, divided by the order of the cyclic subgroup generated by the distinguished point G. That is, nh is the order of the elliptic curve, where n is the order of the cyclic subgroup generated by the distinguished point G.

<em>H0</em>.definition: The null hypothesis; i.e., the statement that the sequence is random.

<em>HMAC-hash</em>.definition: The HMAC algorithm using the hash function, HASH (e.g., HASHcould be SHA-1). See FIPS 198-1 for the specification of the HMAC algorithm using one of the approved hash functions.

<em>i</em>.definition: A counter taking integer values in the interval [1, 2r-1] that is encoded as a bit string of length r; used as an input to each invocation of a PRF in the counter mode and (optionally) in the feedback and double-pipeline iteration modes.

<em>IDP, IDR, IDU, IDV</em>.definition: Identifier bit strings for parties P, R, U, and V, respectively.

<em>In</em>.definition: Block of data representing the Input Block n

<em>incs(X)</em>.definition: The output of incrementing the right-most s bits of the bit string X, regarded as the binary representation of an integer, by 1 modulo 2s.

<em>Independent</em>.definition: Two random variables X and Y are independent if they do not convey information about each other. Receiving information about X does not change the assessment of the probability distribution of Y (and vice versa).

<em>int(X)</em>.definition: The integer for which the bit string X is a binary representation. len(X) The bit length of the bit string X.

<em>j</em>.definition: The index to a sequence of data blocks or data segments ordered from left to right.

<em>Key management product</em>.definition: A key management product is a cryptographic key (symmetric or asymmetric) or certificate used for encryption, decryption, digital signature, or signature verification; and other items, such as certificate revocation lists and compromised key lists, obtained by trusted means from the same source, which validate the authenticity of keys or certificates. Software that performs either a security or cryptographic function (e.g., keying material accounting and control, random number generation, cryptographic module verification) is also considered to be a cryptographic product.

<em>Key specification</em>.definition: A key specification documents the data format, encryption algorithms, hashing algorithms, signature algorithms, physical media, and data constraints for keys required by a cryptographic device and/or application.

<em>Key1</em>.definition: The first component of a TDEA key.

<em>Key2</em>.definition: The second component of a TDEA key.

<em>Key3</em>.definition: The third component of a TDEA key.

<em>KeyData</em>.definition: Keying material other than that which is used for the MacKey employed in key confirmation.

<em>KEYn</em>.definition: Block of data representing KEY n

<em>Kill Command</em>.definition: A command that readers can send to tags that uses electronic disabling mechanisms to prevent tags from responding to any additional commands.

<em>Klen</em>.definition: The bit length of the block cipher key.

<em>kLen</em>.definition: The length of K in bits

<em>L</em>.definition: An integer specifying the length of the derived keying material KOUT in bits, which is represented as a bit string when it is an input to a key-derivation function.

<em>L-bit Hash Function</em>.definition: A hash function for which the length of the output is L bits.

<em>LCM(a, b)</em>.definition: Least Common Multiple of two positive integers a and b. For example, LCM(4, 6) = 12.

<em>Len</em>.definition: The number of n-byte string elements in a WOTS+ private key, public key, and signature.

<em>Level of Significance (a)</em>.definition: The probability of falsely rejecting the null hypothesis, i.e., the probability of concluding that the null hypothesis is false when the hypothesis is, in fact, true. The tester usually chooses this value; typical values are 0.05, 0.01 or 0.001; occasionally, smaller values such as 0.0001 are used. The level of significance is the probability of concluding that a sequence is non-random when it is in fact random. Synonyms: Type I error, a error.

<em>lg(x)</em>.definition: The base 2 logarithm of the positive real number x.

<em>List</em>.definition: A dynamic-length data structure that stores a sequence of values, where each value is identified by its integer index.

<em>Local performance metric</em>.definition: For a predictor, the length of the longest run of correct predictions

<em>Lock Command</em>.definition: A command that readers can send to a tag to block access to certain information on the tag.

<em>log(x)</em>.definition: The natural logarithm of x: log(x) = loge(x) = ln(x).

<em>log2(x)</em>.definition: Defined as ln(x)/ln(2), where ln is the natural logarithm.

<em>LSBm(X)</em>.definition: The bit string consisting of the m least significant bits of the bit string X.

<em>MacData</em>.definition: A byte string input to the MacTag computation.

<em>MacDataU, (or MacDataV)</em>.definition: MacData associated with party U (or party V, respectively), and used to generate MacTagU (or MacTagV, respectively). Each is a byte string.

<em>MacKey</em>.definition: Key used to compute the MAC; a byte string.

<em>MacKeyLen</em>.definition: The byte length of the MacKey.

<em>MacTagV, (MacTagU)</em>.definition: The MacTag generated by party V (or party U, respectively). Each is a byte string.

<em>Markov model</em>.definition: A model for a probability distribution where the probability that the ith element of a sequence has a given value depends only on the values of the previous n elements of the sequence. The model is called an nth order Markov model.

<em>MaxErrs</em>.definition: The maximum number of times that the output of any implementation of the decryption verification process can be INVALID before the key is retired.

<em>mgfSeed</em>.definition: String from which a mask is derived; a byte string.

<em>Mi</em>.definition: The ith block of the formatted message.

<em>min(x, y)</em>.definition: The minimum ofx and y. For example, if x < y, then min(x, y) = x.

<em>Mlen</em>.definition: The bit length of the message.

<em>Mn*</em>.definition: The final block, possibly a partial block, of the formatted message.

<em>MSBm(X)</em>.definition: The bit string consisting of the m most significant bits of the bit string X.

<em>N</em>.definition: The number of M-bit blocks to be tested.

<em>n</em>.definition: The number of iterations of the PRF needed to generate L bits of keying material.

<em>Narrowest internal width</em>.definition: The maximum amount of information from the input that can affect the output. For example, if f(x) = SHA-1(x) || 01, and x consists of a string of 1000 binary bits, then the narrowest internal width of f(x) is 160 bits (the SHA-1 output length), and the output width of f(x) is 162 bits (the 160 bits from the SHA-1 operation, concatenated by 01).

<em>nBits</em>.definition: The bit length of the RSA modulus n.

<em>nLen</em>.definition: The bit length of the nonce.

<em>Noise source</em>.definition: The component of an entropy source that contains the non-deterministic, entropy-producing activity (e.g., thermal noise or hard drive seek times).

<em>Non-deterministic Random Bit Generat.definition: An RBG that always has access to an entropy source and (when working properly) produces output bitstrings that have full entropy. Often called a True Random Number (or Bit) Generator. (Contrast with a deterministic random bit generator).

<em>Non-physical non-deterministic rando.definition: An entropy source that does not use dedicated hardware but uses system resources (RAM content, thread number etc.) or the interaction of the user (time between keystrokes etc.).

<em>NV</em>.definition: Nonce contributed by party V; a byte string.

<em>On</em>.definition: Block of data representing Output Block n

<em>On-demand test</em>.definition: A type of health test that is available to be run whenever a user or a relying component requests it.

<em>P*n</em>.definition: The last block of the plaintext, which may be a partial block.

<em>p</em>.definition: An FFC domain parameter; an odd prime number that determines the size of the finite field GF(p).

<em>padding</em>.definition: A string consisting of a single “1” bit, followed by zero or more “0” bits.

<em>Physical non-deterministic random bi.definition: An entropy source that uses dedicated hardware or uses a physical experiment (noisy diode(s), oscillators, event sampling like radioactive decay, etc.)

<em>Plen</em>.definition: The bit length of the payload.

<em>Pn</em>.definition: Block of data representing Plaintext n

<em>Predictor</em>.definition: A function that predicts the next value in a sequence, based on previously observed values in the sequence.

<em>PRF(s, x)</em>.definition: A pseudorandom function with seed s and input data x.

<em>PrivKeyU, PrivKeyV</em>.definition: Private key of party U or V, respectively.

<em>Probability model</em>.definition: A mathematical representation of a random phenomenon.

<em>PubKeyU, PubKeyV</em>.definition: Public key of party U or V, respectively.

<em>q</em>.definition: When used as an FFC domain parameter, q is the (odd) prime number equal to the order of the multiplicative subgroup of GF(p)* generated by g. Note that q is a divisor of p – 1.

<em>Q</em>.definition: A bit string representation of the octet length of P.

<em>qInv</em>.definition: Inverse of q modulo p in the CRT format, i.e., q-1 mod p; an integer.

<em>r</em>.definition: An integer that is less than or equal to 32, whose value is the bit length of the agreed-upon binary encoding of a counter i used as input during invocations of the PRF employed by a KDF.

<em>R</em>.definition: The constant within the algorithm for the block multiplication operation.

<em>Raw data</em>.definition: Digitized output of the noise source.

<em>Rb</em>.definition: The constant string for subkey generation for a cipher with block size b.

<em>RESULTn</em>.definition: Block of data representing Plaintext n, if encryption state, or Ciphertext n, if decryption state

<em>rv[0…b]</em>.definition: For bit string rv, rv[0…b] is a substring consisting of the leftmost b+1 bit(s) of rv, where b ≥ 0.

<em>rv_length_indicator</em>.definition: A 16-bit binary representation of the length (in bits) of rv.

<em>rv</em>.definition: The random value that is combined with the message Ms to produce the randomized message M.

<em>S_XMSS</em>.definition: A secret random value used for pseudorandom key generation in XMSS.

<em>s</em>.definition: The standard deviation of a random variable =Öò(x-m)2f ( x )dx.

<em>S</em>.definition: The desired security strength for a digital signature.

<em>s2</em>.definition: The variance of a random variable = (standard deviation)2.

<em>Sample</em>.definition: An observation of the raw data output by a noise source. Common examples of output values obtained by sampling are single bits, single bytes, etc. (The term “sample” is often extended to denote a sequence of such observations; this Recommendation will refrain from that practice.)

<em>Security boundary</em>.definition: A conceptual boundary that is used to assess the amount of entropy provided by the values output from an entropy source. The entropy assessment is performed under the assumption that any observer (including any adversary) is outside of that boundary.

<em>SEED</em>.definition: An optional ECC domain parameter; an initialization value that is used during domain parameter generation that can also be used to provide assurance at a later time that the resulting domain parameters were generated using a canonical process.

<em>sig’</em>.definition: The received digital signature of a randomized message.

<em>sig</em>.definition: A digital signature of a randomized message.

<em>SK_PRF</em>.definition: An n-byte key used to pseudorandomly generate the randomizer r.

<em>Sn</em>.definition: The nth partial sum for values Xi = {-1, +1}; i.e., the sum of the first n values of Xi.

<em>sobs</em>.definition: The observed value which is used as a statistic in the Frequency test.

<em>ss_K</em>.definition: The security strength that can be supported by the key K

<em>ss_Mi</em>.definition: The security strength that can be supported by the combination of the methods used to generate a key Ki, and the methods used to protect it after generation (e.g., during key-transport and/or storage)

<em>Start-up testing</em>.definition: A suite of health tests that are performed every time the entropy source is initialized or powered up. These tests are carried out on the noise source before any output is released from the entropy source.

<em>Stochastic model</em>.definition: A stochastic model is a mathematical description (of the relevant properties) of an entropy source using random variables. A stochastic model used for an entropy source analysis is used to support the estimation of the entropy of the digitized data and finally of the raw data. In particular, the model is intended to provide a family of distributions, which contains the true (but unknown) distribution of the noise source outputs. Moreover, the stochastic model should allow an understanding of the factors that may affect the entropy. The distribution of the entropy source needs to remain in the family of distributions, even if the quality of the digitized data goes down.

<em>Submitter</em>.definition: The party that submits the entire entropy source and output from its components for validation. The submitter can be any entity that can provide validation information as required by this Recommendation (e.g., developer, designer, vendor or any organization).

<em>Symbol</em>.definition: The value of the noise source output (i.e., sample value).

<em>t</em>.definition: The octet length of the MAC.

<em>T192(X)</em>.definition: A truncation function that outputs the most significant (i.e., leftmost) 192 bits of the input bit string X.

<em>Testing laboratory</em>.definition: An accredited cryptographic security testing laboratory.

<em>TEXTn</em>.definition: Block of data representing Plaintext n, if encryption state, or Ciphertext n,

<em>timestamp_signatureTTA</em>.definition: A digital signature that is generated using a TTA’s private signature key.

<em>timestamp_time</em>.definition: The time provided in a timestamp.

<em>timestamp</em>.definition: Contains the time and, possibly, other information; a component of timestamped_data.

<em>timestamped_data</em>.definition: The data on which a digital signature is generated by a TTA.

<em>Tlen</em>.definition: The bit length of the MAC.

<em>TMacTagBits(X)</em>.definition: A truncation function that outputs the most significant (i.e., leftmost) MacTagBits bits of the input string, X, when the bit length of X is greater than MacTagBits; otherwise, the function outputs X. For example, T2(1011) = 10, T3(1011) = 101, and T4(1011) = 1011.

<em>TTA_supplied_info</em>.definition: Additional information that is included in the timestamped_data by a TTA during the generation of a timestamp_signature.

<em>TW(S)</em>.definition: The output of the wrapping function for TKW applied to the string S.

<em>TW-1(C)</em>.definition: The output of the unwrapping function for TKW applied to the string C.

<em>Type I error</em>.definition: Incorrectly rejection of a true null hypothesis.

<em>u</em>.definition: The number of bits in the last plaintext or ciphertext block.

<em>user_supplied_info</em>.definition: Additional information that is provided by an entity when requesting a timestamp from a TTA.

<em>VARIABLEn</em>.definition: Block of data representing the value of VARIABLE for the nth iteration

<em>Vn(obs)</em>.definition: The observed number of runs in a sequence of length n. See Sections 2.3 and 3.3.

<em>Vn</em>.definition: The expected number of runs that would occur in a sequence of length n under an assumption of randomness See Sections 2.3 and 3.3.

<em>W(S)</em>.definition: The output of the wrapping function for KW and KWP applied to the bit string S.

<em>w</em>.definition: The length of a key-derivation key in bits.

<em>W-1(C)</em>.definition: The output of the unwrapping function for KW and KWP applied to the bit string C.

<em>X =? Y</em>.definition: Check for the equality of X and Y.

<em>x -1 mod n</em>.definition: The multiplicative inverse of the integer x modulo the positive integer n. This quantity is defined if and only if x is relatively prime to n. For the purposes of this Recommendation, y = x-1 mod n is the unique integer satisfying the following two conditions:

<em>x mod n</em>.definition: The unique remainder r, 0£ r £ (n – 1), when integer x is divided by positive integer n. For example, 23 mod 7 = 2.

<em>X⊕Y</em>.definition: Bit-wise inclusive-or of two bit-strings X and Y of the same bit length.

<em>X</em>.definition: The smallest integer that is larger than or equal to X. The ceiling of X.

<em>⎾x⏋</em>.definition: The smallest integer that is larger than or equal to X. The ceiling of X. For example, \(\lceil\)8.2\(\rceil\) = 9.

<em>X<< 1</em>.definition: The bit string that results from discarding the leftmost bit of the bit string X and appending a ‘0’ bit on the right.

<em>X>> 1</em>.definition: The bit string that results from discarding the rightmost bit of the bit string X and prepending a ‘0’ bit on the left.

<em>x·y</em>.definition: The product of two integers, x and y.

<em>X2(obs)</em>.definition: The chi-square statistic computed on the observed values. See Sections 2.2, 2.4, 2.5, 2.7, 2.8, 2.10, 2.12, 2.14, and the corresponding sections of Section 3.

<em>X2</em>.definition: The [theoretical] chi-square distribution; used as a test statistic; also, a test statistic that follows the X2 distribution.

<em>Xi</em>.definition: The elements of the string consisting of±1 that is to be tested for randomness, where Xi = 2ei-1.

<em>xj</em>.definition: The total number of times that a given state occurs in the identified cycles. See Section 2.15 and 3.15.

<em>Z</em>.definition: A shared secret (represented as a byte string) that is used to derive secret keying material using a key derivation method.

<i>K<sub>IN</sub></i>.definition: A key-derivation key used as input to a key-derivation function (along with other data) to derive the output keying material KOUT.

<i>K<sub>OUT</sub></i>.definition: Output keying material that is derived from the key-derivation key KIN and other data that were used as input to a key-derivation function.

<i>X&nbsp;</i>:= <i>Y</i>.definition: X is defined to be equal to Y.

<span class=\"math-tex\">\\(\\in\\)</spa.definition: For an element s and a set S, s \(\in\) S, means that s belongs to S.

<span class=\"math-tex\">\\(\\varepsilon.definition: A positive constant that is assumed to be no greater than \(2^{-32}\)

<strong>client</strong>.definition: a machine or software application that accesses a cloud over a network connection, perhaps on behalf of a consumer; and

<strong>cloud consumer or customer</stro.definition: a person or organization that is a customer of a cloud; note that a cloud customer may itself be a cloud and that clouds may offer services to one another;

<strong>cloud provider or provider</stro.definition: an organization that provides cloud services.

<strong>Shall</strong>.definition: The term used to indicate a requirement of a Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) or a requirement that needs to be fulfilled to claim conformance with this Recommendation. Note that shall may be coupled with not to become shall not.

<strong>Should</strong>.definition: The term used to indicate an important recommendation. Ignoring the recommendation could result in undesirable results. Note that should may be coupled with not to become should not.

∅.definition: The empty binary string. That is, for any binary string A,∅ || A = A || ∅= A.

24/7.definition: 24 Hours a Day, Seven Days a Week

2FA.definition: Authentication using two or more factors to achieve authentication. Factors include: (i) something you know (e.g., password/personal identification number [PIN]); (ii) something you have (e.g., cryptographic identification device, token); or (iii) something you are (e.g., biometric).

2TDEA.definition: Two-key Triple Data Encryption Algorithm specified in [NIST SP 800-67].

3TDEA.definition: Three-key Triple Data Encryption Algorithm specified in [NIST SP 800-67].

6LowPANs.definition: IPv6 over Low-Power Wireless Personal Area Networks

AA.definition: An entity, recognized by the Federal PKI Policy Authority or comparable Agency body as having the authority to verify the association of attributes to an identity.

AAD.definition: The input data to the authenticated encryption function that is authenticated but not encrypted.

AAL.definition: A list of applications and application components (libraries, configuration files, etc.) that are authorized to be present or active on a host according to a well-defined baseline.

AAR.definition: A document containing findings and recommendations from an exercise or a test.

ABAC.definition: An access control approach in which access is mediated based on attributes associated with subjects (requesters) and the objects to be accessed. Each object and subject has a set of associated attributes, such as location, time of creation, access rights, etc. Access to an object is authorized or denied depending upon whether the required (e.g., policy-defined) correlation can be made between the attributes of that object and of the requesting subject.

Abbreviated Dialing Numbers.definition: phone book entries kept on the SIM.

absolute error.definition: The absolute difference between the noisy and unaltered versions of a query’s output.

abstraction.definition: View of an object that focuses on the information relevant to a particular purpose and ignores the remainder of the information.

AC.definition: The process of granting or denying specific requests to 1) obtain and use information and related information processing services and 2) enter specific physical facilities (e.g., federal buildings, military establishments, border crossing entrances).

access authority.definition: An entity responsible for monitoring and granting access privileges for other authorized entities.

Access Complexity.definition: reflects the complexity of the attack required to exploit the software feature misuse vulnerability.

access control.definition: The process of granting or denying specific requests to 1) obtain and use information and related information processing services and 2) enter specific physical facilities (e.g., federal buildings, military establishments, border crossing entrances).

Access Control Matrix.definition: A table in which each row represents a subject, each column represents an object, and each entry is the set of access rights for that subject to that object.

access control mechanism.definition: The logical component that serves to receive the access request from the subject, to decide, and to enforce the access decision.

Access Control Model.definition: Formal presentations of the security policies enforced by AC systems, and are useful for proving theoretical limitations of systems. AC models bridge the gap in abstraction between policy and mechanism.

Access Control Policy.definition: Policies that describe who is allowed to access the data and/or which parts of the data.

Access control system.definition: A set of procedures and/or processes, normally automated, which allows access to a controlled area or to information to be controlled, in accordance with pre-established policies and rules.

access cross domain solution.definition: A type of transfer cross domain solution (CDS) that provides access to a computing platform, application, or data residing in different security domains without transfer of user data between the domains.

access level.definition: A category within a given security classification limiting entry or system connectivity to only authorized persons.

access list.definition: A list of users, programs, and/or processes and the specifications of access categories to which each is assigned.

Access Management.definition: Access Management is the set of practices that enables only those permitted the ability to perform an action on a particular resource. The three most common Access Management services you encounter every day perhaps without realizing it are: Policy Administration, Authentication, and Authorization.

Access Point (AP).definition: A device that logically connects wireless client devices operating in infrastructure to one another and provides access to a distribution system, if connected, which is typically an organization’s enterprise wired network.

access profile.definition: Association of a user with a list of protected objects the user may access.

access program (SAP).definition: A program established for a specific class of classified information that imposes safeguarding and access requirements that exceed those normally required for information at the same classification level.

access type.definition: The nature of an access right to a particular device, program, or file (e.g., read, write, execute, append, modify, delete, or create).

Access Vector.definition: reflects the access required to exploit the vulnerability.

Account.definition: An entity in a blockchain that is identified with an address and can send transactions to the blockchain.

account linking.definition: The association of multiple federated identifiers with a single RP subscriber account or the management of those associations.

account recovery.definition: The ability to regain ownership of a subscriber account and its associated information and privileges.

account resolution.definition: The association of an RP subscriber account with information that is already held by the RP prior to the federation transaction and outside of a trust agreement.

accountability.definition: Property that ensures that the actions of an entity may be traced uniquely to the entity.

accounting legend code.definition: A numeric code used to indicate the minimum accounting controls required for items of accountable COMSEC material within the COMSEC material control system (CMCS).

accounting number.definition: A number assigned to an individual item of COMSEC material at its point of origin to facilitate its handling and accounting.

accreditation.definition: Formal declaration by a designated accrediting authority (DAA) or principal accrediting authority (PAA) that an information system is approved to operate at an acceptable level of risk, based on the implementation of an approved set of technical, managerial, and procedural safeguards.

accreditation boundary.definition: Identifies the information resources covered by an accreditation decision, as distinguished from separately accredited information resources that are interconnected or with which information is exchanged via messaging.

accuracy.definition: Closeness of computations or estimates to the exact or true values that the statistics were intended to measure.

accuracy (absolute).definition: The degree of conformity of a measured or calculated value to the true value, typically based on a global reference system. For time, the global reference can be based on the following time scales: UTC, International Atomic Time (TAI), or GPS. For position, the global reference can be WGS 84.

accuracy (relative).definition: The degree of agreement between measured or calculated values among the devices and applications dependent on the position, navigation, or time data at an instant in time.

ACL.definition: A mechanism that implements access control for a system resource by enumerating the system entities that are permitted to access the resource and stating, either implicitly or explicitly, the access modes granted to each entity.

ACM.definition: Implementations of formal AC policy such as AC model. Access control mechanisms can be designed to adhere to the properties of the model by machine implementation using protocols, architecture, or formal languages such as program code.

ACME.definition: A protocol defined in IETF RFC 8555 that provides for the automated enrollment of certificates.

ACP.definition: High-level requirements that specify how access is managed and who may access information under what circumstances.

acquirer.definition: Organization or entity that acquires or procures a product or service.

acquisition.definition: Includes all stages of the process of acquiring product or services, beginning with the process for determining the need for the product or services and ending with contract completion and closeout.

ACRLCS.definition: Access Control Rule Logic Circuit Simulation

activation.definition: The process of inputting an activation factor into a multi-factor authenticator to enable its use for authentication.

activation data.definition: A pass-phrase, personal identification number (PIN), biometric data, or other mechanisms of equivalent authentication robustness used to protect access to any use of a private key, except for private keys associated with System or Device certificates.

activation factor.definition: An additional authentication factor that is used to enable successful authentication with a multi-factor authenticator.

activation secret.definition: A password that is used locally as an activation factor for a multi-factor authenticator.

Activation/Issuance.definition: A process that includes the procurement of FIPS-approved blank PIV Cards or hardware/software tokens (for Derived PIV Credential), initializing them using appropriate software and data elements, personalization of these cards/tokens with the identity credentials of authorized subjects, and pick-up/delivery of the personalized cards/tokens to the authorized subjects, along with appropriate instructions for protection and use.

active attack.definition: An attack on a secure communication protocol where the attacker transmits data to the claimant, Credential Service Provider (CSP), verifier, or Relying Party (RP). Examples of active attacks include man-in- the middle (MitM), impersonation, and session hijacking. [NIST SP 800-63-3, adapted]

active content.definition: Electronic documents that can carry out or trigger actions automatically on a computer platform without the intervention of a user.

active cyber defense.definition: Synchronized, real-time capability to discover, detect, analyze, and mitigate threats and vulnerabilities.

Active Directory.definition: A Microsoft directory service for the management of identities in Windows domain networks.

Active Security Testing.definition: Security testing that involves direct interaction with a target, such as sending packets to a target.

Active state.definition: A lifecycle state for a key in which the key may be used to cryptographically protect information (e.g., encrypt plaintext or generate a digital signature), to cryptographically process previously protected information (e.g., decrypt ciphertext or verify a digital signature) or both.

Active Tag.definition: A tag that relies on a battery for power.

Activities.definition: An assessment object that includes specific protection-related pursuits or actions supporting a system that involves people (e.g., conducting system backup operations, monitoring network traffic).

activity.definition: Set of cohesive tasks of a process.

Actor.definition: The source of risk that can result in harmful impact.

Actual Residual Risk.definition: The risk remaining after management has taken action to alter its severity.

Actual State.definition: The observable state or behavior of an assessment object (device, software, person, credential, account, etc.) at the point in time when the collector generates security-related information. In particular, the actual state includes the states or behaviors that might indicate the presence of security defects.

Actuating Capability.definition: The ability to change something in the physical world.

AD.definition: Input data to the CCM generation-encryption process that is authenticated but not encrypted.

Ad Hoc HIEs.definition: An Ad Hoc HIE occurs when two healthcare organizations exchange health information, usually under the precondition of familiarity and trust, using existing and usual office infrastructure such as mail, fax, e-mail and phone calls.

Ad Hoc Network.definition: A wireless network that dynamically connects wireless client devices to each other without the use of an infrastructure device, such as an access point or a base station.

adaptability.definition: The property of an architecture, design, and implementation that can accommodate changes to the threat model, mission or business functions, systems, and technologies without major programmatic impacts.

Additional Authenticated Data.definition: The input data to the authenticated encryption function that is authenticated but not encrypted.

Additional input.definition: Information known by two parties that is cryptographically bound to the secret keying material being protected using the encryption operation.

add-on security.definition: Incorporation of new or additional hardware, software, or firmware safeguards in an operational information system.

Address Resolution Protocol (ARP).definition: A protocol used to obtain a node’s physical address. A client station broadcasts an ARP request onto the network with the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the target node with which it wishes to communicate, and with that address the node responds by sending back its physical address so that packets can be transmitted to it.

addressable.definition: To meet the addressable implementation specifications, a covered entity or business associate must (i) assess whether each implementation specification is a reasonable and appropriate safeguard in its environment, when analyzed with reference to the likely contribution to protecting the electronic protected health information; and (ii) as applicable to the covered entity or business associate - (A) Implement the implementation specification if reasonable and appropriate; or (B) if implementing the implementation specification is not reasonable and appropriate—(1) document why it would not be reasonable and appropriate to implement the implementation specification; and (2) implement an equivalent alternative measure if reasonable and appropriate.

adequate security.definition: Meets minimum tolerable levels of security as determined by analysis, experience, or a combination of both and is as secure as reasonably practicable (i.e., incremental improvement in security would require an intolerable or disproportionate deterioration of meeting other system objectives, such as those for system performance, or would violate system constraints).

ADFSL.definition: Annual Conference on Digital Forensics, Security and Law

adj-RIB-In.definition: Routes learned from inbound update messages from BGP peers.

adj-RIB-Out.definition: Routes that the BGP router will advertise, based on its local policy, to its peers.

Adjudicative Entity.definition: An agency authorized by law, Executive Order, designation by the Security Executive Agent, or delegation by the Suitability & Credentialing Executive Agent to make an adjudication. Adjudication has the meaning provided in [Executive Order 13764], “(a) ‘Adjudication’ means the evaluation of pertinent data in a background investigation, as well as any other available information that is relevant and reliable, to determine whether a covered individual is: (i) suitable for Government employment; (ii) eligible for logical and physical access; (iii) eligible for access to classified information; (iv) eligible to hold a sensitive position; or (v) fit to perform work for or on behalf of the Government as a Federal employee, contractor, or non-appropriated fund employee.”

Administrative domain.definition: A logical collection of hosts and network resources (e.g., department, building, company, organization) governed by common policies.

administrative incident (COMSEC).definition: A violation of procedures or practices dangerous to security that is not serious enough to jeopardize the integrity of a controlled cryptographic item (CCI), but requires corrective action to ensure the violation does not recur or possibly lead to a reportable COMSEC incident.

Advanced Encryption Standard.definition: A U.S. Government-approved cryptographic algorithm that can be used to protect electronic data. The AES algorithm is a symmetric block cipher that can encrypt (encipher) and decrypt (decipher) information.

advanced key processor.definition: A cryptographic device that performs all cryptographic functions for a management client node and contains the interfaces to 1) exchange information with a client platform, 2) interact with fill devices, and 3) connect a client platform securely to the primary services node (PRSN).

advanced persistent threat.definition: An adversary that possesses sophisticated levels of expertise and significant resources that allow it to create opportunities to achieve its objectives by using multiple attack vectors including, for example, cyber, physical, and deception. These objectives typically include establishing and extending footholds within the IT infrastructure of the targeted organizations for purposes of exfiltrating information, undermining or impeding critical aspects of a mission, program, or organization, or positioning itself to carry out these objectives in the future. The advanced persistent threat pursues its objectives repeatedly over an extended period; adapts to defenders’ efforts to resist it; and is determined to maintain the level of interaction needed to execute its objectives.

Advanced Persistent Threats.definition: An adversary with sophisticated levels of expertise and significant resources, allowing it through the use of multiple different attack vectors (e.g., cyber, physical, and deception) to generate opportunities to achieve its objectives, which are typically to establish and extend footholds within the information technology infrastructure of organizations for purposes of continually exfiltrating information and/or to undermine or impede critical aspects of a mission, program, or organization, or place itself in a position to do so in the future; moreover, the advanced persistent threat pursues its objectives repeatedly over an extended period of time, adapting to a defender’s efforts to resist it, and with determination to maintain the level of interaction needed to execute its objectives.

Advanced Technology Attachment.definition: Magnetic media interface specification. Also known as “IDE” –IntegratedDrive Electronics.

adversarial example.definition: A modified testing sample that induces misclassification or misbehav­ior of a machine learning model at deployment time.

Adversarial Machine Learning.definition: Attacks that exploit the statistical, data-based nature of ma­chine learning systems.

adversary.definition: A malicious entity whose goal is to determine, to guess, or to influence the output of an RBG.

adverse consequence.definition: An undesirable consequence associated with a loss.

adverse cybersecurity event.definition: Any event with a potentially negative impact on cybersecurity.

adversity.definition: The conditions that can cause a loss of assets (e.g., threats, attacks, vulnerabilities, hazards, disruptions, and exposures).

advisory.definition:
Notification of significant new trends or developments regarding the threat to the information systems of an organization. This notification may include analytical insights into trends, intentions, technologies, or tactics of an adversary targeting information systems. 
Rationale: General definition of a commonly understood term.

AE.definition: The function of GCM in which the plaintext is encrypted into the ciphertext, and an authentication tag is generated on the AAD and the ciphertext.

AES.definition: Advanced Encryption Standard (as specified in FIPS 197).

AESAVS.definition: Advanced Encryption Standard Algorithm Validation Suite

AES-CMAC.definition: Advanced Encryption Standard-Cipher-based Message Authentication Code

AES-GMAC.definition: Advanced Encryption Standard-Galois Message Authentication Code

AES-XCBC.definition: Advanced Encryption Standard-eXtended Cipher Block Chaining

Affine Transformation.definition: A transformation consisting of multiplication by a matrix followed by the addition of a vector.

After Action Report.definition: A document containing findings and recommendations from an exercise or a test.

agency.definition: Any executive department, military department, government corporation, government controlled corporation, or other establishment in the executive branch of the government (including the Executive Office of the President), or any independent regulatory agency, but does not include: (i) the Government Accountability Office; (ii) the Federal Election Commission; (iii) the governments of the District of Columbia and of the territories and possessions of the United States, and their various subdivisions; or (iv) government-owned contractor-operated facilities, including laboratories engaged in national defense research and production activities.

Agency Dashboard.definition: An organizational-level dashboard that: a) collects data from a collection system; and b) shows detailed assessment object-level data and assessment object-level defects to organizationally authorized personnel.

Agent.definition: Software programs that can interact with their environment, receive information, and undertake self-directed actions in service of a larger, externally-specified goal.

Aggregate.definition: To combine several more-specific prefixes into a less-specific prefix.

Aggregated Information.definition: Information elements collated on a number of individuals, typically used for the purposes of making comparisons or identifying patterns.

agility.definition: The property of a system or an infrastructure that can be reconfigured, in which resources can be reallocated, and in which components can be reused or repurposed so that cyber defenders can define, select, and tailor cyber courses of action for a broad range of disruptions or malicious cyber activities.

agreement.definition: Mutual acknowledgement of terms and conditions under which a working relationship is conducted, or goods are transferred between parties. EXAMPLE: contract, memorandum, or agreement

AHRQ.definition: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality

AI.definition: (1) Any artificial system that performs tasks under varying and unpredictable circumstances without significant human oversight, or that can learn from experience and improve performance when exposed to data sets. (2) An artificial system developed in computer software, physical hardware, or other context that solves tasks requiring human-like perception, cognition, planning, learning, communication, or physical action. (3) An artificial system designed to think or act like a human, including cognitive architectures and neural networks. (4) A set of techniques, including machine learning, that is designed to approximate a cognitive task. (5) An artificial system designed to act rationally, including an intelligent software agent or embodied robot that achieves goals using perception, planning, reasoning, learning, communicating, decision making, and acting.

AIAA.definition: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

AID.definition: A globally unique identifier of a card application as defined in ISO/IEC 7816-4.

air gap.definition: An interface between two systems at which (a) they are not connected physically and (b) any logical connection is not automated (i.e., data is transferred through the interface only manually, under human control).

Air Traffic Organization.definition: Authorization to Operate; One of three possible decisions concerning an issuer made by a Designated Authorizing Official after all assessment activities have been performed stating that the issuer is authorized to perform specific PIV Card and/or Derived Credential issuance services.

Airdrop.definition: A distribution of digital tokens to a list of blockchain addresses.

alert.definition: Notification that a specific attack has been directed at an organization’s information systems.

Algorithm.definition: A clearly specified mathematical process for computation; a set of rules that, if followed, will give a prescribed result.

Algorithm originator-usage period.definition: The period of time during which a specific cryptographic algorithm may be used by originators to apply protection to data (e.g., encrypt or generate a digital signature).

Algorithm security lifetime.definition: The estimated time period during which data protected by a specific cryptographic algorithm remains secure.

algorithmic optimization.definition: The application of mathematical formulae to calculate the aggregate cost-benefit to the enterprise, given the estimated costs, in a purely mechanical approach.

Allan deviation.definition: [See source document for the complete definition.]

allied nation.definition: A nation allied with the U.S. in a current defense effort and with which the U.S. has certain treaties. For an authoritative list of allied nations, contact the Office of the Assistant Legal Adviser for Treaty Affairs, Office of the Legal Adviser, U.S. Department of State, or see the list of U.S. Collective Defense Arrangements at https://www.state.gov.

allocation.definition: The process an organization employs to assign security controls to specific information system components responsible for providing a particular security capability (e.g., router, server, remote sensor).

allowed.definition: The algorithm and key length in a FIPS or SP is safe to use; no security risk is currently known when used in accordance with any associated guidance. The FIPS 140 Implementation Guideline may indicate additional algorithms that are acceptable for use, but not specified in a FIPS or SP.

allowlist.definition: A documented list of specific elements that are allowed, per policy decision. In federation contexts, this is most commonly used to refer to the list of RPs that are allowed to connect to an IdP without subscriber intervention. This concept has historically been known as a whitelist.

all-source intelligence.definition: In intelligence collection, a phrase that indicates that in the satisfaction of intelligence requirements, all collection, processing, exploitation, and reporting systems and resources are identified for possible use and those most capable are tasked.

ALM/PLM.definition: Application Life cycle Management / Product Lifecycle Management

alternate COMSEC account manager.definition: The primary alternate COMSEC Account Manager is an individual designated by proper authority to perform the duties of the COMSEC Account Manager during the temporary authorized absence of the COMSEC Account Manager. Additional alternate COMSEC Account Managers may be appointed, as necessary, to assist the COMSEC Account Manager and maintain continuity of operations.

alternate COMSEC custodian.definition: Individual designated by proper authority to perform the duties of the COMSEC custodian during the temporary absence of the COMSEC custodian.

ambiguity rule.definition: It is assumed that out of publicly available information the contribution of one individual to the cell total can be estimated to within q per cent (q=error before publication); after the publication of the statistic the value can be estimated to within p percent (p=error after publication). In the (p,q) rule the ratio p/q represents the information gain through publication. If the information gain is unacceptable, the cell is declared as confidential. The parameter values p and q are determined by the statistical authority and, thus, define the acceptable level of information gain. In some [National Statistical Organizations] the values of p and q are confidential.

American Registry for Internet Numbers.definition: The American Registry for Internet Numbers for Canada, the United States of America, and many Caribbean and North Atlantic Islands.

AML.definition: Attacks that exploit the statistical, data-based nature of ma­chine learning systems.

Analysis.definition: The examination of acquired data for its significance and probative value to the case.

Analysis Approach.definition: The approach used to define the orientation or starting point of the risk assessment, the level of detail in the assessment, and how risks due to similar threat scenarios are treated.

Analytic Systems.definition: IT systems that process the information outputs produced by middleware. Analytic systems may be comprised of databases, data processing software, and Web services.

Anomalous Event Response and Recovery Ma.definition: See Capability, Anomalous Event Response and Recovery Management.

anomaly.definition: Condition that deviates from expectations based on requirements specifications, design documents, user documents, or standards, or from someone’s perceptions or experiences.

anonymity.definition: Condition in identification whereby an entity can be recognized as distinct, without sufficient identity information to establish a link to a known identity.

anonymization.definition: A process that removes the association between the identifying dataset and the data subject.

anonymized data.definition: data from which the patient cannot be identified by the recipient of the information

Anonymized Information.definition: Previously identifiable information that has been de-identified and for which a code or other association for re-identification no longer exists.

anonymous identifier.definition: identifier of a person which does not allow the unambiguous identification of the natural person

ANSI/INCITS.definition: American National Standards Institute/International Committee for Information Technology Standards

anticipated re-identification rate.definition: When an organization contemplates performing re-identification, the re-identification rate that the resulting de-identified data are likely to have.

Anti-Forensic.definition: A technique for concealing or destroying data so that others cannot access it.

anti-jam.definition: The result of measures to resist attempts to interfere with communications reception.

anti-signal fingerprint.definition: Result of measures used to resist attempts to uniquely identify a particular transmitter based on its signal parameters.

anti-signal spoof.definition: Result of measures used to resist attempts to achieve imitative or manipulative communications deception based on signal parameters.

anti-spoof.definition: Countermeasures taken to prevent the unauthorized use of legitimate identification & authentication (I&A) data, however it was obtained, to mimic a subject different from the attacker.

anti-tamper.definition: Systems engineering activities intended to prevent physical manipulation or delay exploitation of critical program information in U.S. defense systems in domestic and export configurations to impede countermeasure development, unintended technology transfer, or alteration of a system due to reverse engineering.

Antivirus Software.definition: A program specifically designed to detect many forms of malware and prevent them from infecting computers, as well as cleaning computers that have already been infected.

AO.definition: A senior (federal) official or executive with the authority to formally assume responsibility for operating an information system at an acceptable level of risk to organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, and the Nation.

AODR.definition: An organizational official acting on behalf of an authorizing official in carrying out and coordinating the required activities associated with security authorization or privacy authorization.

AP.definition: A set of filter processes that are arranged in a linear order using one-way inter-process communications to transfer data between processes. The linear flow is enforced with mandatory and discretionary access control mechanisms.

APCO.definition: Association of Public Safety Communications Officials

APCP.definition: American Hospital Association Preferred Cybersecurity Provider

APDU.definition: A part of the application layer in the Open Systems Interconnection Reference model that is used for communication between two separate device's applications. In the context of smart cards, an APDU is the communication unit between a smart card reader and a smart card. The structure of the APDU is defined by [ISO 7816-4].

Aperiodic Templates Test.definition: The purpose of this test is to reject sequences that exhibit too many occurrences of a given non-periodic (aperiodic) pattern.

API.definition: A system access point or library function that has a well-defined syntax and is accessible from application programs or user code to provide well-defined functionality.

APNIC.definition: The Regional Internet Registry for the Asia Pacific region that allocates and registers Internet resources in its region.

Applicability Statement.definition: A complex logical expression to describe an IT platform, formed out of individual CPE names and references to checks. Applicability statements are used to designate which platforms particular guidance, policies, etc. apply to.

applicant.definition: An individual applying for a PIV Card or derived PIV credential. The applicant may be a current or prospective federal hire, a federal employee, or a contractor.

applicant reference.definition: A representative of the applicant who can vouch for the identity of the applicant, specific attributes related to the applicant, or conditions relative to the context of the individual (e.g., emergency status, homelessness).

application.definition: A hardware/software system implemented to satisfy a particular set of requirements. In this context, an application incorporates a system used to satisfy a subset of requirements related to the verification or identification of an end user’s identity so that the end user’s identifier can be used to facilitate the end user’s interaction with the system.

application allowlisting.definition: A list of applications and application components (libraries, configuration files, etc.) that are authorized to be present or active on a host according to a well-defined baseline.

Application Firewall.definition: A firewall that uses stateful protocol analysis to analyze network traffic for one or more applications.

application interconnection.definition: A logical communications link between two or more applications operated by different organizations or within the same organization but within different authorization boundaries used to exchange information or provide information services (e.g., authentication, logging).

Application Interface Capability.definition: The ability for other computing devices to communicate with an IoT device through an IoT device application.

Application Layer.definition: Layer of the TCP/IP protocol stack that sends and receives data for particular applications such as DNS, HTTP, and SMTP.

Application Level Gateway (ALG).definition: Application Level Gateways (ALGs) are application specific translation agents that allow an application (like VOIP) on a host in one address realm to connect to its counterpart running on a host in different realm transparently. An ALG may interact with NAT to set up state, use NAT state information, modify application specific payload and perform whatever else is necessary to get the application running across disparate address realms.

Application Programming Interface (API).definition: A system access point or library function that has a well-defined syntax and is accessible from application programs or user code to provide well-defined functionality.

Application Protocol Data Unit.definition: A part of the application layer in the Open Systems Interconnection Reference model that is used for communication between two separate device's applications. In the context of smart cards, an APDU is the communication unit between a smart card reader and a smart card. The structure of the APDU is defined by [ISO 7816-4].

Application Translation.definition: A function that converts information from one protocol to another.

Application virtualization.definition: A virtual implementation of the application programming interface (API) that a running application expects to use.

Application-Proxy Gateway.definition: A firewall capability that combines lower-layer access control with upper layer-functionality, and includes a proxy agent that acts as an intermediary between two hosts that wish to communicate with each other.

application-specific integrated circuits.definition: A digital or analog circuit, custom-designed and/or custom-manufactured to perform a specific function. An ASIC is not reconfigurable and cannot contain additional instructions.

apply cryptographic protection.definition: Depending on the algorithm, to encrypt or sign data, generate a hash function or Message Authentication Code (MAC), or establish keys (including wrapping and deriving keys).

approval status.definition: Used to designate usage by the U.S. Federal Government.

approval to operate.definition: The official management decision issued by a designated accrediting authority (DAA) or principal accrediting authority (PAA) to authorize operation of an information system and to explicitly accept the residual risk to agency operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), agency assets, or individuals.

approved.definition: An algorithm or technique for a specific cryptographic use that is specified in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation, adopted in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation, or specified in a list of NIST-approved security functions.

approved cryptography.definition: An encryption algorithm, hash function, random bit generator, or similar technique that is Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS)-approved or NIST-recommended. Approved algorithms and techniques are either specified or adopted in a FIPS or NIST recommendation.

Approved entropy source.definition: An entropy source that has been validated as conforming to [NIST SP 800-90B].

Approved security function.definition:
A security function (e.g., cryptographic algorithm, cryptographic key management technique, or authentication technique) that is either 
a) Specified in an Approved standard, 
b) Adopted in an Approved standard and specified either in an appendix of the Approved standard or in a document referenced by the Approved standard, or 
c) Specified in the list of Approved security functions.

Approximate Entropy Test.definition: The purpose of the test is to compare the frequency of overlapping blocks of two consecutive/adjacent lengths (m and m+1) against the expected result for a normally distributed sequence.

APT.definition: An adversary with sophisticated levels of expertise and significant resources, allowing it through the use of multiple different attack vectors (e.g., cyber, physical, and deception), to generate opportunities to achieve its objectives which are typically to establish and extend its presence within the information technology infrastructure of organizations for purposes of continually exfiltrating information and/or to undermine or impede critical aspects of a mission, program, or organization, or place itself in a position to do so in the future; moreover, the advanced persistent threat pursues its objectives repeatedly over an extended period of time, adapting to a defender’s efforts to resist it, and with determination to maintain the level of interaction needed to execute its objectives.

architecture.definition: A highly structured specification of an acceptable approach within a framework for solving a specific problem. An architecture contains descriptions of all the components of a selected, acceptable solution while allowing certain details of specific components to be variable to satisfy related constraints (e.g., costs, local environment, user acceptability).

Architecture Constructs.definition: Design structures that can serve as the basic building blocks for a Notional Architecture.

architecture description.definition: A work product used to express an architecture.

Architecture Design Principles.definition: Best practices derived from large-scale information-sharing implementations that serve as the overall guidance for building security and privacy services for HIEs.

architecture framework.definition: Conventions, principles, and practices for the description of architectures established within a specific domain of application and/or community of stakeholders.

architecture view.definition: A work product expressing the architecture of a system from the perspective of specific system concerns.

architecture viewpoint.definition: A work product establishing the conventions for the construction, interpretation, and use of architecture views to frame specific system concerns.

area under the curve.definition: A measure of the ability of a classifier to distinguish between classes in machine learning. A higher AUC means that a model performs better when dis­tinguishing between the two classes. AUC measures the entire two-dimensional area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve.

ARIN.definition: The American Registry for Internet Numbers for Canada, the United States of America, and many Caribbean and North Atlantic Islands.

Array.definition: A fixed-size data structure that stores a collection of elements, where each element is identified by its integer index or indices.

artificial intelligence.definition: (1) Any artificial system that performs tasks under varying and unpredictable circumstances without significant human oversight, or that can learn from experience and improve performance when exposed to data sets. (2) An artificial system developed in computer software, physical hardware, or other context that solves tasks requiring human-like perception, cognition, planning, learning, communication, or physical action. (3) An artificial system designed to think or act like a human, including cognitive architectures and neural networks. (4) A set of techniques, including machine learning, that is designed to approximate a cognitive task. (5) An artificial system designed to act rationally, including an intelligent software agent or embodied robot that achieves goals using perception, planning, reasoning, learning, communicating, decision making, and acting.

artificial intelligence model.definition: A component of an information system that implements AI technology and uses computational, statistical, or machine-learning techniques to produce outputs from a given set of inputs.

artificial intelligence red-teaming.definition: A structured testing effort to find flaws and vulnerabilities in an AI system, often in a controlled environment and in collaboration with developers of AI.

artificial intelligence system.definition: Any data system, software, hardware, application, tool, or utility that operates in whole or in part using AI.

AS.definition: An Autonomous System specifies a network, mostly an organization that can own or announce network addresses to the Internet.

ASCII.definition: American Standard Code for Information Interchange

ASDSO.definition: Association of State Dam Safety Officials

Asia-Pacific Network Information Centre.definition: The Regional Internet Registry for the Asia Pacific region that allocates and registers Internet resources in its region.

aspect.definition: The parts, features, and characteristics used to describe, consider, interpret, or assess something.

assembly.definition: An item forming a portion of an equipment, that can be provisioned and replaced as an entity and which normally incorporates replaceable parts and groups of parts.

assertion.definition: A verifiable statement from an IdP to an RP that contains information about an end user. Assertions may also contain information about the end user’s authentication event at the IdP.

assertion injection attack.definition: In the context of a federated protocol, consists of an attacker attempting to force an RP to accept or process an assertion or assertion reference in order to gain access to the RP or deny a legitimate subscriber access to the RP. The attacker does this by taking an assertion or assertion reference and injecting it into a vulnerable RP.

assertion presentation.definition: The method by which an assertion is transmitted to the RP.

assessment.definition: The process of identifying risks to organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, and the Nation, resulting from the operation of an information system. A part of risk management incorporates threat and vulnerability analyses, and considers mitigations provided by security controls planned or in place.

assessment approach.definition: The approach used to assess risk and its contributing risk factors, including quantitatively, qualitatively, or semi-quantitatively.

Assessment Boundary.definition: The scope of (assessment objects included in) an organization’s ISCM implementation to which assessment of objects is applied. Typically, assessment boundary includes an entire network to its outside perimeter.

Assessment Completeness.definition: The degree to which the continuous monitoring-generated, security-related information is collected on all assessment objects for all applicable defect checks within a defined period of time.

Assessment Criterion/Criteria.definition: A rule (or rules) of logic to allow the automated or manual detection of defects. Typically, the assessment criterion in ISCM defines what in the desired state specification is compared to what in the actual state and the conditions that indicate a defect.

assessment element.definition: A specific ISCM concept to be evaluated in the context of a specific ISCM Process Step.

assessment element attribute.definition: An item of information that is specifically applicable to an assessment element, such as the source for the assessment element or risk management level to which the element applies.

assessment element text.definition: A statement that should be true for a well-implemented ISCM program. This statement is the evaluation criteria part of an assessment element.

assessment findings.definition: Assessment results produced by the application of an assessment procedure to a security control or control enhancement to achieve an assessment objective; the execution of a determination statement within an assessment procedure by an assessor that results in either a satisfied or other than satisfied condition.

assessment method.definition: One of three types of actions (i.e., examine, interview, test) taken by assessors in obtaining evidence during an assessment.

assessment object.definition: The item (i.e., specifications, mechanisms, activities, individuals) upon which an assessment method is applied during an assessment.

assessment objective.definition: A set of determination statements that expresses the desired outcome for the assessment of a security control or control enhancement.

assessment plan.definition: The objectives for the control assessments and a detailed roadmap of how to conduct such assessments.

assessment procedure.definition: A set of assessment objectives and an associated set of assessment methods and assessment objects.

assessment results.definition: The output or outcome of an assessment.

Assessment Timeliness.definition: The degree to which the continuous monitoring-generated, security-related information is collected within the specified period of time (or frequency).

assessor.definition: The individual, group, or organization responsible for conducting a security or privacy control assessment.

asset.definition:
A distinguishable entity that provides a service or capability. Assets are people, physical entities, or information located either within or outside the United States and employed, owned, or operated by domestic, 

foreign, public, or private sector organizations.

asset identification.definition: SCAP constructs to uniquely identify assets (components) based on known identifiers and/or known information about the assets.

Asset Identification Element.definition: A complete, bound expression of an asset identification using the constructs defined in this specification.

Asset Report.definition: A collection of content (or link to content) about an asset.

Asset Report Request.definition: A collection of structured information used as input to generate an asset report. An asset report request may be of any format and may have different contexts depending on the nature of the request. For instance, the request may be written in a control language that dictates how the request is to be propagated and executed. The request may also be written as a formal definition without reference to how the request is to be executed. The request may also be a prose description that must be interpreted and executed by a person. These examples are not exhaustive.

asset reporting format.definition: SCAP data model for expressing the transport format of information about assets (components) and the relationships between assets and reports.

Asset Reporting Format Report.definition: The collection of all assets, report requests, reports, and relationships for a given instance of ARF.

Asset Tag.definition: Simple key value attributes that are associated with a platform (e.g., location, company name, division, or department).

assignment statement.definition: A control parameter that allows an organization to assign a specific, organization-defined value to the control or control enhancement (e.g., assigning a list of roles to be notified or a value for the frequency of testing). See organization-defined control parameters and selection statement.

Associated Data.definition: Data that is authenticated but not encrypted.

Association.definition: A relationship for a particular purpose. For example, a key is associated with the application or process for which it will be used.
