World Geodetic System 1984.definition: An Earth-centered, Earth-fixed terrestrial reference system and geodetic datum. WGS 84 is based on a consistent set of constants and model parameters that describe the Earth’s size, shape, gravity, and geomagnetic fields. WGS 84 is the standard U.S. Department of Defense definition of a global reference system for geospatial information and is the reference system for GPS. It is consistent with the International Terrestrial Reference System (ITRS).

Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave.definition: A wireless metropolitan area network (WMAN) technology based on the IEEE 802.16 family of standards used for a variety of purposes, including, but not limited to, fixed last-mile broadband access, long-range wireless backhaul, and access layer technology for mobile wireless subscribers operating on telecommunications networks.

Wrapped keying material.definition: Keying material that has been encrypted and its integrity protected using an approved key wrapping algorithm and a key wrapping key in order to disguise the value of the underlying plaintext key.

wrapping function.definition: The keyed, length-preserving permutation that is applied to an enlarged form of the plaintext within the authenticated-encryption function to produce the ciphertext.

Write.definition: Fundamental operations of an information system that results only in the flow of information from an actor to storage media.

Write Once, Read Many.definition:
Write-Once Read Many. 
Also see CD-R.

Write Protection.definition: Hardware or software methods of preventing data from being written to a disk or other medium.

Write-Blocker.definition: A device that allows investigators to examine media while preventing data writes from occurring on the subject media.

WS.definition: A computer used for tasks such as programming, engineering, and design.

WYSIWYG.definition: what you see is what you get

x ´ y.definition: The product of x and y.

X.509 certificate.definition: The X.509 public-key certificate or the X.509 attribute certificate, as defined by the ISO/ITU-T X.509 standard. Most commonly (including in this document), an X.509 certificate refers to the X.509 public-key certificate.

X.509 public key certificate.definition:
The public key for a user (or device) and a name for the user (or device), together with some other information, rendered unforgeable by the digital signature of the certification authority that issued the certificate, encoded in the format defined in the ISO/ITU-T X.509 standard. 
Also known as X.509 Certificate.

XACML.definition: A general purpose language for specifying access control policies.

XCCDF Content.definition: A file conforming to the XCCDF schema.

XML.definition: a flexible text format designed to describe data for electronic publishing.

XML Encryption.definition: A process/mechanism for encrypting and decrypting XML documents or parts of documents. World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) XML Encryption Syntax and Processing, http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlenc-core

XML Information Security Marking (XML-IS.definition: Provides definitions of and implementation of the XML attributes used as containers for Controlled Access Program Coordination Office (CAPCO)-defined sensitivity and classification markings to be applied to all or part of an XML document. The markings are implemented using ICML.

XML Schema.definition: A language for describing the defining the structure, content and semantics of XML documents.

XML Signature.definition: A mechanism for ensuring the origin and integrity of XML documents. XML Signatures provide integrity, message authentication, or signer authentication services for data of any type, whether located within the XML that includes the signature or elsewhere.

XOF.definition:
A function on bit strings in which the output can be extended to any desired length. Approved XOFs (e.g., those specified in FIPS 202) are designed to satisfy the following properties as long as the specified output length is sufficiently long to prevent trivial attacks

1. (One-way) It is computationally infeasible to find any input that maps to any new pre-specified output.

2. (Collision-resistant) It is computationally infeasible to find any two distinct inputs that map to the same output.

XPath.definition: Used to define the parts of an XML document, using path expressions.

XQuery.definition: Provides functionality to query an XML document.

XSS.definition: Cross-Site Scripting is a security flaw found in some Web applications that enables unauthorized parties to cause client-side scripts to be executed by other users of the Web application.

XTS.definition: XEX Tweakable Block Cipher with Ciphertext Stealing

xy.definition: The product of x and y.

zero day attack.definition: An attack that exploits a previously unknown hardware, firmware, or software vulnerability.

zero fill.definition: To fill unused storage locations in an information system with a numeric value of zero.

Zero Trust.definition: A collection of concepts and ideas designed to minimize uncertainty in enforcing accurate, least privilege per-request access decisions in information systems and services in the face of a network viewed as compromised.

Zero Trust Architecture.definition: A security model, a set of system design principles, and a coordinated cybersecurity and system management strategy based on an acknowledgement that threats exist both inside and outside traditional network boundaries. The zero trust security model eliminates implicit trust in any one element, component, node, or service and instead requires continuous verification of the operational picture via real-time information from multiple sources to determine access and other system responses.

zeroization.definition: An action applied to a key or a piece of secret data. After a key or a piece of secret data is destroyed, no information about its value can be recovered.

zeroize.definition: To remove or eliminate the key from a cryptographic equipment or fill device.

Zero-Knowledge Proof.definition: A cryptographic scheme where a prover is able to convince a verifier that a statement is true, without providing any more information than that single bit (that is, that the statement is true rather than false).

ZKP.definition: A cryptographic scheme where a prover is able to convince a verifier that a statement is true, without providing any more information than that single bit (that is, that the statement is true rather than false).

zone of control.definition: Three dimensional space surrounding equipment that processes classified and/or controlled unclassified information (CUI) within which TEMPEST exploitation is not considered practical or where legal authority to identify and remove a potential TEMPEST exploitation exists.

Zone Signing Key (ZSK).definition: An authentication key that corresponds to a private key used to sign a zone. Typically a zone signing key will be part of the same DNSKEY RRSet as the key signing key whose corresponding private key signs this DNSKEY RRSet, but the zone signing key is used for a slightly different purpose and may differ from the key signing key in other ways, such as validity lifetime. Designating an authentication key as a zone signing key is purely an operational issue: DNSSEC validation does not distinguish between zone signing keys and other DNSSEC authentication keys, and it is possible to use a single key as both a key signing key and a zone signing key. See also “key signing key.”

ZT.definition: A collection of concepts and ideas designed to minimize uncertainty in enforcing accurate, least privilege per-request access decisions in information systems and services in the face of a network viewed as compromised.

ZTA.definition: A security model, a set of system design principles, and a coordinated cybersecurity and system management strategy based on an acknowledgement that threats exist both inside and outside traditional network boundaries. The zero trust security model eliminates implicit trust in any one element, component, node, or service and instead requires continuous verification of the operational picture via real-time information from multiple sources to determine access and other system responses.
